questions.text: Sustained gonadotropin secretion requires which of the following patterns of gonadotropin-releasing hormone (GnRH) secretion?

questions.text: A 24-year-old woman comes to the gynecology OPD seeking contraceptive advice. She is married and has a 4-year-old son. She is a known epileptic and is on lamotrigine. Which of the following contraceptives will require you to increase the dose of lamotrigine?
questions.explanation:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ When prescribing contraceptives to women on lamotrigine, it's essential to consider potential drug interactions. Combined oral contraceptives can reduce lamotrigine levels due to hepatic enzyme induction, potentially necessitating an increase in the lamotrigine dose to maintain its efficacy. Non-hormonal options or progestin-only contraceptives may be preferable for women on lamotrigine to avoid such interactions.

questions.text: A 22-year-old boy was involved in an argument but quickly worsened into a street brawl with the use of knives. He was examined in the emergency department and found to have a bleeding stab wound in his left flank. A urine specimen revealed frank blood. Of the organs listed below, which one is least likely to be injured?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Inferior vena cava

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ In the case of a left flank stab wound, the organ least likely to be injured is the inferior vena cava, due to its more central and right-sided location in the abdomen. Other organs located on the left side, such as the spleen, left suprarenal gland, and parts of the stomach, are at higher risk of injury in this scenario.
  • ➤ In the case of a left flank stab wound, the organ least likely to be injured is the inferior vena cava, due to its more central and right-sided location in the abdomen.
  • ➤ Other organs located on the left side, such as the spleen, left suprarenal gland, and parts of the stomach, are at higher risk of injury in this scenario.

questions.text: A 75-year-old man presented to the OPD with mild headache, vomiting, and features of raised ICP. There was no history of any trauma in the last few hours. His son revealed that the man had slipped and fallen in the bathroom a month back and had hit his head back then. He is currently on warfarin because he has had a mechanical valve replacement in the past. What is the diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Chronic subdural haemorrhage

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In an elderly patient on anticoagulation presenting with headache, vomiting, and features of raised ICP weeks after a minor trauma, the diagnosis is most likely chronic subdural hemorrhage. This condition is characterized by the stretching and tearing of bridging veins in the subdural space, particularly in the context of cerebral atrophy and anticoagulant use, leading to a collection of blood that can gradually increase in size and cause symptoms due to mass effect.
  • ➤ In an elderly patient on anticoagulation presenting with headache, vomiting, and features of raised ICP weeks after a minor trauma, the diagnosis is most likely chronic subdural hemorrhage.
  • ➤ This condition is characterized by the stretching and tearing of bridging veins in the subdural space, particularly in the context of cerebral atrophy and anticoagulant use, leading to a collection of blood that can gradually increase in size and cause symptoms due to mass effect.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man with a history of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease presents to the clinic with a persistent cough and weight loss. questions.explanation:

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A child presents with complaints of anaemia/thrombocytopenia and bone pain. On Examination, hepatosplenomegaly was observed, and light microscopy reveals crumpled tissue paper appearance. The enzyme defect is:
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Glucocerebrosidase

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ The "crumpled tissue paper" appearance of cells in light microscopy, along with symptoms like anemia, thrombocytopenia, bone pain, and hepatosplenomegaly, strongly suggests Gaucher's disease, which is caused by a deficiency in the enzyme glucocerebrosidase.
  • ➤ The "crumpled tissue paper" appearance of cells in light microscopy, along with symptoms like anemia, thrombocytopenia, bone pain, and hepatosplenomegaly, strongly suggests Gaucher's disease, which is caused by a deficiency in the enzyme glucocerebrosidase.

questions.text: A 75-year-old man was found on ophthalmoscopic examination to have bilateral papilledema and congestion of both retinal veins. The cause of the condition was found to be a rapidly expanding intracranial tumor. Which of the following statements is not correct?

options.label: A
options.text: The optic nerves are surrounded by sheaths derived from the pia mater, arachnoid mater, and dura mater.

options.label: B
options.text: The intracranial subarachnoid space extends forward around the optic nerve as far as the back of the eyeball.

options.label: C
options.text: The ciliary ganglion is situated between the proximal part of medial rectus and optic nerve.

options.label: D
options.text: The nerve to medial rectus is seen inferior to the optic nerve.

questions.correct_answer: C. The ciliary ganglion is situated between the proximal part of medial rectus and optic nerve.
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) The ciliary ganglion is situated between the proximal part of medial rectus and optic nerve.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ The ciliary ganglion is located laterally to the optic nerve in the orbit, not between the optic nerve and the medial rectus. It is associated with the control of pupil constriction and lens accommodation, not the visual pathway directly affected by papilledema in the presence of an intracranial tumor.
  • ➤ The ciliary ganglion is located laterally to the optic nerve in the orbit, not between the optic nerve and the medial rectus.
  • ➤ It is associated with the control of pupil constriction and lens accommodation, not the visual pathway directly affected by papilledema in the presence of an intracranial tumor.

questions.text: A pediatrician is evaluating a 3-year-old girl with a confirmed diagnosis of Rett syndrome. Which clinical characteristics are most consistent with this diagnosis? Gastrointestinal disturbances are also commonly observed.

questions.text: A 14-month-old boy is being evaluated for recurrent, indolent skin infections and gingivitis.   • ➤ Delayed separation of the umbilical cord, recurrent skin infections, and a deficiency in wound healing are indicative of Leukocyte Adhesion Deficiency (LAD), most commonly due to a defect in integrins, specifically the beta-2 integrin subunit (CD18). This condition impairs leukocyte adhesion and migration to sites of infection.
  • ➤ Delayed separation of the umbilical cord, recurrent skin infections, and a deficiency in wound healing are indicative of Leukocyte Adhesion Deficiency (LAD), most commonly due to a defect in integrins, specifically the beta-2 integrin subunit (CD18).

questions.text: A 60-year-old woman presents for a routine checkup. She has a sedentary lifestyle and her BMI is 26. She used to smoke 1 pack/day but has recently stopped. She was advised calcium and vitamin D supplementation at her last checkup but has not been taking these. She has no significant medical history. A DEXA scan is done which shows her T score as -2.5. What is the most appropriate treatment option for her?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ For a postmenopausal woman with a sedentary lifestyle and a DEXA scan showing a T-score of -2.5 (indicating osteoporosis), the most appropriate initial treatment option would be bisphosphonates. They are effective in increasing bone mineral density and reducing fracture risk in osteoporosis. Calcium and vitamin D supplementation are also important but usually serve as adjunct therapy.
  • ➤ For a postmenopausal woman with a sedentary lifestyle and a DEXA scan showing a T-score of -2.5 (indicating osteoporosis), the most appropriate initial treatment option would be bisphosphonates.
  • ➤ They are effective in increasing bone mineral density and reducing fracture risk in osteoporosis.
  • ➤ Calcium and vitamin D supplementation are also important but usually serve as adjunct therapy.

questions.text: A 35-year-old female presents with a painless, palpable mass in her neck. Thyroid function tests reveal normal levels of thyroid hormones. Which of the following histological type of carcinoma thyroid most commonly metastasizes to lymph nodes?

questions.text: A 70-year-old lady got compression fracture of L1 vertebra. There is no neurological deficit to this patient. What advise will you give for this patient?

questions.text: A 55-year-old female came for a routine blood check-up. The lab technician collected about 5 ml of blood at 8 am in a plain vacutainer for various function tests including blood sugar and the sample was processed at 11 am and report was given at 12pm. All laboratory tests results were normal except blood glucose which was found to be 48 mg/dl. Which enzyme is responsible for the findings?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Hexokinase

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ Hexokinase activity in blood cells can lead to a reduction in the glucose concentration of a blood sample if it is not processed quickly. This enzyme catalyses the first step in glycolysis, converting glucose to glucose-6-phosphate, thereby consuming glucose in the sample and potentially leading to falsely low glucose measurements if there is a delay in sample processing.
  • ➤ Hexokinase activity in blood cells can lead to a reduction in the glucose concentration of a blood sample if it is not processed quickly.
  • ➤ This enzyme catalyses the first step in glycolysis, converting glucose to glucose-6-phosphate, thereby consuming glucose in the sample and potentially leading to falsely low glucose measurements if there is a delay in sample processing.

questions.text: A 11-year-old child presents with shortness of breath and difficulty exercising. On examination, a fixed, split-second heart sound is heard, and there is a palpable thrill felt on the chest. Hilar dance was seen on fluoroscopy. What is the likely diagnosis?

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ An atrial septal defect typically presents with a fixed, split-second heart sound and can cause symptoms such as shortness of breath and difficulty with exercise due to increased pulmonary flow and right heart volume overload. Hilar dance on fluoroscopy further supports the diagnosis by indicating increased blood flow through the pulmonary arteries.
  • ➤ An atrial septal defect typically presents with a fixed, split-second heart sound and can cause symptoms such as shortness of breath and difficulty with exercise due to increased pulmonary flow and right heart volume overload.
  • ➤ Hilar dance on fluoroscopy further supports the diagnosis by indicating increased blood flow through the pulmonary arteries.

questions.text: A 25-year-old primi is undergoing induction of labor for past dates. Her Bishop score is 1. Which would not be a preferred method?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ When inducing labor, the Bishop score is used to assess the readiness of the cervix. A low Bishop score indicates an unfavorable cervix, suggesting that cervical ripening methods such as PGE2 or PGE1 should be used before attempting more aggressive methods like ARM or oxytocin infusion. ARM is not preferred with a low Bishop score due to increased risks without adequate cervical readiness.
